definitions.definition: to look at and understand the meaning of written or printed words or symbols

examples.text: She's still **learning to read**.
Some children can **read and write** before they go to school.
I can't read your writing.
Can you read music?
I'm trying to read the map.
He speaks and reads Arabic fluently.
Most children can read by the age of seven.
She had great difficulty learning to read and write.
He learned to read when he was three.
Some of the kids here can't even read and write.

definitions.definition: to go through written or printed words, etc. in silence or speaking them to other people
definitions.sensetop: read to somebody/yourselfread somethingread something to somebody/yourselfread somebody something

examples.text: I'm going to go to bed and read.
The book is very easy to read.
He liked reading to his grandchildren.
to **read a book/magazine/newspaper**
to **read an article/a report/a letter/a blog/a review**
Have you read any Steinbeck *(= novels by him)*?
one of the most **widely read** books in the world
I have read every single post in this entire thread.
I didn't have time to read the novel.
I just **finished reading** your recent article.
He **read** the poem **aloud**.
Go on—read it to us.
Statements from police officers were read to the court.
She **read** us a **story**.
I read the words out loud.
Will you read me a story?
What are you reading at the moment?
She reads voraciously.
I used to read to my younger brothers at bedtime.
Could you read the poem aloud to us please?
We teach students to read critically.
She read from the letter.
She read avidly from an early age—books, magazines, anything.
I've just read your interesting article.
I regularly read ‘Time’.
I read a story to my son every night.
I listen to my children reading aloud.
He remembers everything he reads in books.
She's not someone who reads for pleasure.
He read her letter with interest.
Make sure you read the instructions correctly.

definitions.definition: to discover or find out about somebody/something by reading
definitions.sensetop: read about/of something (in something)read that…read somethingread something in somethingread something on something

examples.text: I read about the accident in the local paper.
I read that he had resigned.
I **read somewhere** that women are starting companies at record rates.
I can't remember where I read it.
That's the most ridiculous thing I have ever read!
Don't believe everything you read in the papers.
I read it on the internet.
Hogan had read about her death in the paper.
I had read of the case in the local newspaper.
I read about it in today's paper.

definitions.definition: to guess what somebody else is thinking

examples.text: Tell me what you want—I can't read your mind!

definitions.definition: to look at the movements of somebody’s lips to learn what they are saying
to understand something in a particular way

examples.text: How do you read the present situation?
Silence must not always be read as consent.

definitions.definition: to have something written on it; to be written in a particular way

examples.text: The sign read ‘No admittance’.
I’ve changed the last paragraph. It now reads as follows…

definitions.definition: to give a particular impression when read

examples.text: Generally, the article reads very well.
The poem reads like *(= sounds as if it is)* a translation.

definitions.definition: to show a particular weight, pressure, etc.

examples.text: What does the thermometer read?

definitions.definition: to get information from a measuring instrument

examples.text: A man came to read the gas meter.

definitions.definition: to hear and understand somebody speaking on a radio set

examples.text: ‘Do you read me?’ ‘I'm reading you loud and clear.’

definitions.definition: to replace one word, etc. with another when correcting a text
definitions.sensetop: read A for Bread B as A

examples.text: For ‘madam’ in line 3 read ‘madame’.

definitions.definition: to study a subject, especially at a university

examples.text: I read English at Oxford.
She's reading for a law degree.

definitions.definition: to take information from a disk

examples.text: The computer could not read the disk at all.
to read a file into a computer

definitions.definition: to look for or discover a meaning in something that is not openly stated

examples.text: Reading between the lines, I think Clare needs money.

definitions.definition: to understand easily what somebody is thinking or feeling
used to tell somebody to listen carefully to what you are saying

examples.text: Read my lips: no new taxes *(= I promise there will be no new taxes)*.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody with force that they must not do something
to accept something without discussing it

examples.text: Can we take it as read that you want the job?

wordOrigin: Old English rǣdan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch raden and German raten ‘advise, guess’. Early senses included ‘advise’ and ‘interpret (a riddle or dream)’.
